Award.AwardTitle: A Direct Experimental Link Between Atomic-Scale and Macroscale Friction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Friction governs the operating limitations, durability, energy consumption, and control of virtually every machine including those with important implications for healthcare, economic prosperity, and national security. Although we sense friction at the macroscale, it is known to originate at the atomic-scale. Despite having scientific roots dating back to da Vinci, our understanding of how these fundamental atomic-scale interactions contribute to everyday friction remains poor. This award will support a controlled study of interfacial friction from the atomic-scale to the practical-scale to elucidate this relationship. The results will be used to develop a testable model of frictional scaling. Such a model is needed to inform materials design and surface engineering efforts for friction control applications. The results will translate to practice through our existing collaborations with industrial partners whose products all make extensive use of the model solid lubricant material studied here. Lastly, the project funds an educational effort that reaches 6-12th grade populations, university students and faculty, and the broader scientific community.

Atomic force microscopy enables fundamental studies of atomic-scale friction phenomena whereas traditional tribometry measures friction at the more practical macro-scale. A lack of the tools needed to study the length, force, and speed scales in between has prevented the community from linking machine friction to its fundamental origins. The team on this project has developed two key technologies to enable this project: 1) a method to reliably calibrate and quantitatively measure atomic-scale friction and 2) a microtribometer capable of bridging measurements from the atomic-scale to those from the macroscale. The objective of this project is to stitch these length-scales together by carefully controlling material, load, probe radius and speed in the gap between the atomic and macro size-scales. The results will be used to develop a testable scaling model for interfacial friction that will enable our materials scientist collaborators to design materials and engineer interfaces for improved frictional control. To promote translation of the science to broader audiences, the team will: 1) publish in the most visible journals; 2) present at high impact conferences; 3) educate collaborators; 4) inject practices and outcomes into instruction; 5) mentor graduate and undergraduate students in research; and 6) engage 7-12th grade populations by conducting outreach activities on campus and at tribology conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

A direct experimental link between atomic-scale and macroscale friction

Designing more reliable and energy efficient machines and devices requires that we begin to connect our understanding about fundamental mechanisms of friction and wear, which are well-established, with their tribological manifestations in macroscale engineering systems. To date, this has been impossible due to an experimental dead-zone between fundamental (atomic force microscope) and practical (e.g. tribometer) friction measurement devices. The overarching goal of this work was to develop the tools and methodologies needed to eliminate this measurement gap. To this end, this project achieved the following outcomes:

1)   We increased the loads available in the atomic force microscope (AFM) by ~100x and demonstrated the ability to quantify super-low friction coefficients (>0.01) at normal forces up to 3.4 mN; to our knowledge, this is by far the greatest force ever reported for AFM friction measurement.

2)   We developed direct calibration methods to quantify normal and frictional forces during ultra-high force nanotribology measurements in the AFM that are traceable to absolute measurement standards. The ability to quantify these forces with high confidence was a critical barrier in this project.

3)   We improved the force control and measurement sensitivity of a traditional tribometer by >1,000x; we were successful in resolving 100 nN forces with a fundamentally macroscale instrument by the project’s conclusion.

4)   We developed methods to mount colloidal spheres of the same size, shape, and material to the measurement sensors (cantilevers) of the AFM and tribometer so both instruments could be used to study identical material systems under identical mechanical conditions.

5)   We developed new methods to reliably produce and qualify model tribological surfaces, which comprised large, stable, and well-adhered sheets of single crystal MoS2, to mitigate the risk of plowing, subsurface damage, wear, third bodies, and other confounding phenomena that are thought to mask fundamental tribological processes in macroscale contacts. Resonance curves from a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) substrate were used for quality control of these model surfaces.       

6)   We demonstrated our ability to ‘bridge the measurement gap’ by quantifying friction of steel on single crystal MoS2 from 1 mN to 3.4 mN in the AFM and from 100 mN to 10 mN in our custom tribometer. Measurements between instruments showed no more variation than measurements between probes at the same conditions in the AFM, which demonstrates that they are comparable measurement systems under overlapping experimental conditions.

7)   We bridged the speed gap as part of an ROA supplement awarded in the final year, by integrating our tribometer (nm/s to mm/s) with a QCM-based microtribometer capable of quantifying friction at 1 m/s in collaboration with Prof. Borovsky from St. Olaf College. We were successful in quantifying friction of a single tribological system at speeds that varied by 10,000x.

In summary, this project was successful in bridging the gaps between fundament and practical, nanoscale and macroscale, low speed and high speed friction measurements. These tools have unlocked an entirely new area of tribology research at the intersection of fundamental and practical – these enabling technologies are the primary intellectual merits of the project. The PI and his group are actively using these tools to directly probe the ‘fundamentals of macroscale friction’ for the first time. Because these tools were derived from existing knowledge and best-practices, they are ripe for use by other researchers who can compound the potential impacts of this project and accelerate our progress as a community toward true design of vastly improved tribological systems and machines – these are the primary broad impacts of this project.
